reasoning: The critique targets a real strand in the essay (space-resource allocation and implied need to ‘pick a wise rule’), but that strand is not the core thesis, which is mainly about the size/fragility of the eutopian target rather than the strategic dynamics of getting there; if the critique landed, it would mostly affect a sub-argument and the essay’s practical/rhetorical posture (centrality ~0.25). The game-theoretic point is somewhat forceful—publicly framing a situation as cosmic-stakes can exacerbate racing/defection incentives—yet it doesn’t directly undercut the essay’s main claim that near-best futures are a narrow target; if anything, it can reinforce ‘hard to achieve’ by adding another obstacle. It also relies on speculative claims about how this specific essay changes incentives (strength modest). Many individual claims are plausible but not established (correctness mid). The argument is clear and focused, with little fluff (high clarity, low dead weight) and it sticks to one main issue (single-issue high). Overall it raises an interesting implementation concern but poses only a small-to-moderate threat to the position as stated.
title: "Moral analysis can worsen the very risks it identifies"
